abstract.text: The Linux directory share for Rosetta.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: This directory share exposes the Rosetta directory from the host file system to the guest. The example below shows the process of creating a
, and then associating the Rosetta directory share with the VM configuration.
For complete instructions on installing Rosetta see
, which includes additional information about checking for Rosetta availability, mounting the directory share, and registering the Rosetta runtime binary to run Intel binaries in a guest VM.
For information on using a custom kernel to enhance Rosetta performance, see

abstract.text: Create virtual machines and run macOS and Linux-based operating systems.
The base class for a directory share.
The base class for a directory sharing device configuration.
Caching options for an abstract socket.
Constants that describe the availability and installation status of Rosetta.
An abstract class that defines UNIX socket-based caching options for Rosetta.
The Linux directory share for Rosetta.
Socket values you specify to configure Rosetta’s caching capabilities.
A value that indicates the current state of Rosetta’s availability.
The value that enables translation caching and configures the socket communication type for Rosetta.
Creates a new Rosetta directory share, or returns an error if Rosetta isn’t installed.
Starts the installation of Rosetta.
The value that enables translation caching and configures the socket communication type for Rosetta.
Sets the Rosetta caching options using the options you specify.
An object that represents caching options for a UNIX domain socket.
An object that describes a directory share for multiple directories.
A directory on the host that you can expose to a guest.
An object that defines the directory share for a single directory.
An object that manages the overall state and configuration of your VM.
The environment attributes and list of devices to use during the configuration of macOS or Linux VMs.
A view that allows user interaction with a VM.
Improve Rosetta performance by adding support for the total store ordering (TSO) memory model to your Linux kernel.
Run x86_64 Linux binaries under ARM Linux on Apple silicon.

doc://com.apple.virtualization/documenta.title: Running Intel Binaries in Linux VMs with Rosetta

abstract.text: The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
